word_mapping.translation: older sibling (used to call staff politely)

vocabulary.details: This is the most common way to get a server's attention. To be polite, men add ครับ (khrap) and women add ค่ะ (kha). Example: 'พี่ครับ' (Pee khrap). For much older staff, you can use 'ป้า' (bpaa - 'aunt') or 'ลุง' (lung - 'uncle').

vocabulary.thai: ขอเมนูหน่อย

azure_pron_mapping.translation: a little (softening particle for a request)

vocabulary.details: A casual and polite way to ask for the menu. The word 'หน่อย' (noi) softens the request. For an English menu, ask 'ขอเมนูภาษาอังกฤษหน่อย' (khaw menu phaa-saa ang-grit noi), where ภาษาอังกฤษ (phaa-saa ang-grit) means 'English language'.

vocabulary.thai: สั่งอาหารได้ไหม
vocabulary.details: Use this when you are ready to order. An even more casual way is just to say 'สั่งได้เลย' (sang dai loei), which means 'Ready to order now'.

vocabulary.thai: มีอะไรแนะนำไหม
vocabulary.details: A great way to find a restaurant's best dishes. A simpler, very common alternative is 'อะไรอร่อย' (arai aroi?), meaning 'What's delicious?'.
This is the most common, local way to ask for the bill. It literally means 'collect money'. Another very common phrase, borrowed from English, is 'เช็คบิล' (chek bin).

The most common and direct way to order. Example: 'เอาผัดไทย' (ao phat thai - 'I'll take Pad Thai'). It's not rude. A slightly more polite version is 'ขอ...' (khaw...), meaning 'Can I have...'. Example: 'ขอผัดไทย' (khaw phat thai).

This is the common, everyday way to say 'eat here'. Staff will often ask 'กินที่นี่หรือกลับบ้าน' (gin tee nee reu glap baan?) - 'Eat here or take away?'. The more formal/polite word for 'to eat' is 'ทาน' (taan), so 'ทานที่นี่' (taan tee nee) is also correct and polite.
Literally 'return home', this is the standard phrase for a to-go order. Another common phrase is 'ห่อกลับบ้าน' (haw glap baan), which means 'wrap to take home'.

vocabulary.thai: ขอน้ำเปล่าแก้วนึง
vocabulary.details: A very common way to ask for water. 'แก้วนึง' (gaew neung) is a casual shortening of 'หนึ่งแก้ว' (neung gaew). For a bottle, use 'ขวด' (khuat).
An essential phrase. You can also specify 'เผ็ดน้อย' (phet noi) for 'a little spicy' or 'เผ็ดมาก' (phet maak) for 'very spicy'.
Crucial for coffee and tea. For no sweetness, say 'ไม่หวาน' (mai waan - 'not sweet') or 'ไม่ใส่น้ำตาล' (mai sai nam-dtaan - 'don't add sugar').
Very useful for omitting ingredients. Example: 'ไม่ใส่ผักชี' (mai sai phak chi) for 'don't add cilantro'. To add something, just say 'ใส่...' (sai...).

vocabulary.thai: อันนี้อะไร
vocabulary.details: Perfect for night markets. Simply point and ask. The slightly more formal version is 'นี่คืออะไร' (Nee kheu arai).
A simple and appreciated compliment. To emphasize, say 'อร่อยมาก' (aroi maak - 'very delicious').

vocabulary.thai: ไม่ต้องทอน
vocabulary.details: Used when paying cash to leave a tip. Tipping is not mandatory but is common for good service.
The standard polite way to say thank you. Remember to add ครับ (khrap) for males and ค่ะ (kha) for females.
Essential for asking the price. Point and say 'อันนี้เท่าไหร่' (an nee tao rai - 'How much is this one?').

vocabulary.english: Can I have spoon and fork?
vocabulary.thai: ขอช้อนส้อมหน่อย
vocabulary.details: The standard cutlery in Thailand is a spoon and fork. Spoon is for eating, fork is for pushing.

vocabulary.thai: ขอตะเกียบหน่อย
vocabulary.details: Useful for noodle dishes or at Chinese/Japanese style restaurants.

vocabulary.thai: ขอทิชชู่หน่อย

azure_pron_mapping.translation: May I have / Can I have

vocabulary.details: The English word 'tissue' is commonly used. The formal Thai word is 'กระดาษชำระ' (gra-daat cham-ra).

word_mapping.translation: to eat a strict vegetarian/vegan diet

vocabulary.details: The most common way to express a strict vegetarian/vegan diet (no animal products, garlic, or strong herbs). For a broader ovo-lacto vegetarian diet, the word is 'มังสวิรัติ' (mangsawirat).

word_mapping.translation: to be allergic to; to lose

vocabulary.details: Crucial for allergies. Replace 'กุ้ง' (goong) with any other allergen, such as 'ถั่ว' (tua - 'nuts').
Useful for stir-fried dishes. You can also say 'ขอน้ำมันน้อยๆ' (khaw nam-man noi-noi) for 'a little oil, please'.
Use for drinks or soup. Example: 'เอากาแฟร้อน' (ao ga-fae rawn - 'I'll have a hot coffee').
The default for most drinks. Example: 'เอาชาเย็น' (ao chaa yen - 'I'll take an iced tea').

vocabulary.thai: น้ำผลไม้ปั่น
vocabulary.details: A popular drink. Specify the fruit, e.g., 'น้ำมะม่วงปั่น' (nam ma-muang bpan - 'mango smoothie').

vocabulary.thai: ขอเบียร์อีกขวด

azure_pron_mapping.translation: to ask for; please; may I have

vocabulary.details: A simple way to order another round. 'อีก' (eek) means 'another' or 'more'.
Use this when you want to pay separately. The opposite is 'รวมบิล' (ruam bin - 'combine bill').

vocabulary.thai: รับบัตรไหม
vocabulary.details: A shortened, common way to ask. The full phrase is 'รับบัตรเครดิตไหม' (rap bat credit mai). Good to ask, as many smaller places are cash only.

vocabulary.thai: ไม่ใส่น้ำแข็ง
vocabulary.details: Useful for drinks. 'น้ำ' (nam) is 'water' and 'แข็ง' (khaeng) is 'hard'.
A very common protein. Example: 'เอาผัดกะเพราหมู' (ao phat ga-prao moo - 'I'll have stir-fried holy basil with pork').
Another common protein. Example: 'ข้าวมันไก่' (khao man gai - 'Hainanese chicken rice').
Refers to beef, but can also mean 'meat' in general. To be specific, say 'เนื้อวัว' (neua wua). Example: 'ก๋วยเตี๋ยวเนื้อ' (guay-dtiao neua - 'beef noodle soup').
Literally 'sea'. Used for mixed seafood dishes. Example: 'ข้าวผัดทะเล' (khao phat tha-leh - 'seafood fried rice').
A common addition. See also 'ไข่ดาว' (khai dao - 'fried egg') and 'ไข่เจียว' (khai jiao - 'omelette').
A popular topping. Request it by saying 'เพิ่มไข่ดาว' (perm khai dao - 'add a fried egg').
A Thai-style omelette, often served over rice. 'ข้าวไข่เจียว' (khao khai jiao) is a simple, popular meal.
The staple food. For plain steamed rice, ask for 'ข้าวสวย' (khao suay - 'beautiful rice'). For sticky rice, ask for 'ข้าวเหนียว' (khao niao).

vocabulary.thai: ก๋วยเตี๋ยว

azure_pron_mapping.thai: ก๋วยเตี๋ยว

word_mapping.thai: ก๋วยเตี๋ยว

vocabulary.details: A general term for noodle dishes. There are many types, like 'เส้นใหญ่' (sen yai - 'wide rice noodles') and 'เส้นเล็ก' (sen lek - 'thin rice noodles').
Useful for ordering vegetable dishes. Example: 'ผัดผักรวม' (phat phak ruam - 'stir-fried mixed vegetables').
A core flavor. If a dish is too salty, you can say 'เค็มไป' (khem bpai - 'too salty').
Another core flavor. If you like sour flavors, you can request 'เปรี้ยวๆ' (bpriao bpriao).
A hugely popular dish. Specify the meat, e.g., 'ผัดกะเพราไก่' (phat ga-prao gai). Often served on rice 'ราดข้าว' (raat khao).
A classic one-plate meal. Specify the protein, such as 'ข้าวผัดกุ้ง' (khao phat goong - 'shrimp fried rice').
Thailand's famous stir-fried noodle dish. Usually comes with shrimp 'กุ้ง' (goong) or tofu 'เต้าหู้' (dtao-hoo).

vocabulary.thai: แกงเขียวหวาน
vocabulary.details: A famous Thai curry. The name means 'sweet green curry', but it can be very spicy. Usually made with chicken 'ไก่' (gai).
A classic northeastern dish. There are many versions, like 'ส้มตำไทย' (som tam thai - with peanuts) and 'ส้มตำปูปลาร้า' (som tam bpoo bplaa-raa - with crab and fermented fish sauce).
One of Thailand's most famous soups. 'ต้มยำ' (tom yam) is the general name for hot and sour soups.
A milder, creamy coconut soup with galangal as the dominant flavor.
Extremely useful for pointing. Example: 'เอาอันนี้' (ao an nee - 'I'll take this one').
Used for pointing at something a little further away. Example: 'อันนั้นอะไร' (an nan arai - 'What is that one?').
Useful for getting a table. Example: 'โต๊ะสำหรับสองคน' (dto sam-rap song khon - 'A table for two people').
Helpful if you need an extra chair. Example: 'ขอเก้าอี้อีกตัว' (khaw gao-ee eek dtua - 'Can I have another chair?').
Also used as a classifier for dishes. Example: 'ขอจานเปล่า' (khaw jaan bplao - 'Can I have an empty plate?').
Mainly used for soups and noodle dishes. Example: 'ก๋วยเตี๋ยวชามนี้' (guay-dtiao chaam nee - 'This bowl of noodles').
The classifier for drinks in a cup/glass. Example: 'เบียร์สองแก้ว' (bia song gaew - 'two glasses of beer').
The classifier for bottled drinks. Example: 'น้ำขวดหนึ่ง' (nam khuat neung - 'one bottle of water').
The classifier for canned drinks. Example: 'โค้กกระป๋อง' (coke gra-bpong - 'a can of coke').
When ordering, specify hot 'ร้อน' (rawn) or iced 'เย็น' (yen). Example: 'กาแฟเย็นหวานน้อย' (ga-fae yen waan noi - 'iced coffee, less sweet').
The famous Thai iced tea is 'ชาไทยเย็น' (chaa thai yen). For Chinese tea, ask for 'ชาร้อน' (chaa rawn).
Used in many drinks. Pink milk, 'นมเย็น' (nom yen), is a popular sweet drink.
Widely available, often freshly squeezed.

vocabulary.thai: น้ำมะพร้าว
vocabulary.details: A refreshing drink, often served directly in the coconut.
Literally 'sweet things'. Ask 'มีของหวานอะไรบ้าง' (mee khong waan arai baang?) - 'What desserts do you have?'.

vocabulary.thai: ข้าวเหนียวมะม่วง

word_mapping.thai: ข้าวเหนียว

vocabulary.details: The most famous Thai dessert, especially when mangoes are in season.
A very common way to say you're hungry is 'หิวข้าว' (hio khao - 'hungry for rice'), which implies wanting a meal.
A polite way to decline more food. 'อิ่ม' (Im) on its own means 'full'.
A very common colloquial phrase. Use this if a waiter approaches but you haven't decided yet. A more formal way is 'สักครู่' (sak khruu).
Specifies that you want a dish served over a plate of rice. Example: 'กะเพราหมูราดข้าว' (ga-prao moo raat khao).

vocabulary.thai: เป็นกับข้าว
vocabulary.details: Use this when ordering several dishes to be shared. 'กับข้าว' (gap khao) refers to main dishes eaten alongside rice.
Say this after a dish name to request a larger portion (for a higher price). Example: 'ผัดไทยพิเศษ' (phat thai pi-set).
A popular choice for many dishes, especially 'ผัดกะเพราหมูกรอบ' (phat ga-prao moo grop).
A quintessential street food, often eaten with sticky rice 'ข้าวเหนียว' (khao niao).

vocabulary.thai: ก๋วยเตี๋ยวเรือ

word_mapping.thai: ก๋วยเตี๋ยว

vocabulary.details: A famous type of noodle soup with a rich, dark broth, traditionally sold from boats.
A popular comfort noodle dish made with wide rice noodles 'เส้นใหญ่' (sen yai) and dark soy sauce.

vocabulary.thai: ห้องน้ำอยู่ไหน
vocabulary.details: An essential question. 'ห้อง' (hong) means 'room' and 'น้ำ' (nam) means 'water'.
A useful phrase when communication gets difficult.

vocabulary.thai: พูดอังกฤษได้ไหม
vocabulary.details: The common, shortened version. The full phrase is 'พูดภาษาอังกฤษได้ไหม' (phuut phaa-saa ang-grit dai mai), where ภาษา (phaa-saa) means 'language'.

vocabulary.thai: ไม่ใส่น้ำตาล
vocabulary.details: More specific than 'ไม่หวาน' (mai waan - 'not sweet'). Guarantees no sugar is added.

vocabulary.thai: พริกน้ำปลา
vocabulary.details: The quintessential Thai table condiment. Ask for it by saying 'ขอพริกน้ำปลา' (khaw phrik nam-bplaa).

vocabulary.thai: ที่นี่มีคนนั่งไหม
vocabulary.transliteration: Tee nee mee khon nang mai
vocabulary.details: Useful in crowded food courts. A simpler way is to just point and ask 'ว่างไหม' (waang mai?) - 'Is it free?'.

vocabulary.thai: เอาเหมือนกัน
vocabulary.details: Use this when your friend orders something and you want the exact same thing.
A polite way to say you're just browsing at a market stall when a vendor approaches you.
A very common phrase for leaving the table for a moment (e.g., to go to the restroom).
The staff will likely ask you this. The more formal version is 'กี่ท่าน' (gee thân).
A common response to 'กี่คน' (Gee khon). Just change the number as needed.

vocabulary.thai: ไม่เอาผักชี
vocabulary.details: A more assertive way to say it than 'ไม่ใส่' (mai sai). It means 'I don't want cilantro'. A lifesaver for those who dislike it.

vocabulary.thai: ไม่ใส่ผงชูรส
vocabulary.details: Useful for those with sensitivities. 'ผง' (phong) means 'powder' and 'ชูรส' (chu-rot) means 'to enhance flavor'.

vocabulary.thai: กินเผ็ดไม่ได้
vocabulary.details: A more emphatic way to state your preference. The formal version uses 'ทาน' (taan) instead of 'กิน' (gin).

vocabulary.thai: อันนี้เผ็ดไหม
vocabulary.details: A good question to ask before ordering a new dish. Point at the menu item and ask this.
The universal way to say 'cheers' in Thailand when clinking glasses with friends. A more formal toast might use 'ไชโย' (chai-yo).
Literally 'hungry for water', this is the standard way to say you are thirsty.

vocabulary.thai: เพิ่มไข่ดาว
vocabulary.details: A very common request for dishes like 'ผัดกะเพรา' (phat ga-prao). You can also just say 'ไข่ดาวด้วย' (khai dao duay) - 'with a fried egg too'.
The standard noodle used in Pad Thai and many noodle soups.
The flat, wide noodles used in 'ผัดซีอิ๊ว' (phat see-ew) and 'ราดหน้า' (raat naa).
Yellow, wheat-based egg noodles. Often served 'แห้ง' (haeng - 'dry') or 'น้ำ' (nam - 'in soup').
Translucent noodles made from mung bean starch, used in salads 'ยำวุ้นเส้น' (yam woon-sen) or stir-fries.

vocabulary.thai: แยกน้ำจิ้ม
vocabulary.details: Useful if you want to control the amount of sauce. 'น้ำจิ้ม' (nam-jim) is a general term for any dipping sauce.
A polite way to comment that a dish or drink is sweeter than you'd like. The same structure works for other tastes: 'เค็มไป' (khem bpai - 'too salty'), 'เปรี้ยวไป' (bpriao bpai - 'too sour').

vocabulary.thai: ข้าวเหนียว
vocabulary.details: A staple in Northern and Northeastern Thai cuisine, often eaten with grilled meats or papaya salad.
The standard meat preparation for dishes like 'ผัดกะเพรา' (phat ga-prao).

vocabulary.thai: รวมเซอร์วิสชาร์จยัง

word_mapping.thai: เซอร์วิสชาร์จ

vocabulary.details: Good to know for tipping. 'ยัง' (yang) at the end of a sentence is a casual way to ask '... yet?'. The formal version is 'หรือยัง' (reu yang).

vocabulary.thai: ไม่เอาหลอด
vocabulary.details: A useful phrase for those trying to reduce plastic waste.
An essential word for vegetarians. You can ask for dishes like 'ผัดไทยเต้าหู้' (phat thai dtao-hoo) or 'แกงเขียวหวานเต้าหู้' (gaeng khiao waan dtao-hoo).
A very common and useful question in cafes and restaurants.

vocabulary.english: Can I have the WiFi password?
vocabulary.thai: ขอรหัสไวไฟหน่อย
vocabulary.details: The next logical question after confirming they have WiFi.

vocabulary.thai: คิดเงินผิด
vocabulary.details: A polite but direct way to point out a mistake on the bill. Use 'คิดเงินผิดหรือเปล่า' (khit ngern phit reu bplao - 'Did you perhaps calculate the money wrong?') to be even more gentle.
When ordering steak or grilled meat, repeating the word 'สุก' (suk) implies 'very well cooked'. For medium-rare, you can try 'มีเดียมแรร์' (medium-rare) as the English term is often understood.

vocabulary.thai: เก้าอี้เด็ก
vocabulary.details: A useful phrase for families dining out. You can ask 'มีเก้าอี้เด็กไหม' (mee gao-ee dek mai?) - 'Do you have a child's chair?'.

vocabulary.thai: นั่งตรงนี้ได้ไหม
vocabulary.details: A polite way to ask before taking a seat, especially if you are joining someone or choosing your own table.
